title: 106_s3070
content: The Act may be cited as the "Defective Product Penalty Act of 2000" and pertains to the distribution of a defective product. The "Defective Product Penalty Act of 2000" amends Chapter 11 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on the distribution of defective products. It defines a defective product as one with flaws that make it dangerous beyond accepted risks and serious bodily injury as involving a risk of death, extreme pain, or impairment of bodily functions. The offense involves knowingly and willfully distributing such products. The "Defective Product Penalty Act of 2000" imposes penalties for knowingly introducing defective products into interstate commerce. Offenses include introducing a defective product that causes death (up to 15 years imprisonment) or serious bodily injury (up to 5 years imprisonment). Failure to disclose a defective product also incurs penalties for those with authority over the product. The "Defective Product Penalty Act of 2000" imposes penalties for introducing defective products into interstate commerce without disclosing the defect. Offenses include causing death (up to 15 years imprisonment) or serious bodily injury (up to 5 years imprisonment). SEC. 3. Section 30115 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to require manufacturers to conduct appropriate testing before certification of compliance. Section 30118 is amended to include notification of defects and noncompliance for original equipment. The amendment to Section 30115 of title 49, United States Code, requires manufacturers to review information on accidents or incidents to determine if a defect exists. Manufacturers must notify the Secretary if they suspect a defect or noncompliance. The period for providing remedies for defects and noncompliance is extended to 10 calendar years. The civil penalty is increased to $10,000. Copies of communications about defects and noncompliance must be provided to dealers, owners, or purchasers in the United States or abroad.
